title: The Tale of chmod 777: A Security Horror Story
scenario: A developer runs 'chmod -R 777 /var/www' to fix a permission issue on their web server. What follows is a cautionary tale in 4 chapters.

timeline.description: üéÉ Developer frustrated with permission errors, runs 'chmod -R 777 /var/www'
All web files now have rwxrwxrwx permissions - everyone can read, write, execute
Permission errors fixed! Website works! Developer goes home happy. üè†
üê∫ 2:00 AM - Automated scanner finds the misconfigured server
Attacker uploads malicious PHP file to web directory (777 allows anyone to write)
Malicious script executed - attacker gains shell access to server
Attacker installs backdoor, steals database credentials, downloads customer data
As a 'gift', attacker runs 'chmod -R 000 /var/www' - locks everyone out
‚òÄÔ∏è 9:00 AM - Developer arrives at work to find website completely down
Website shows 403 Forbidden - all files now have 000 permissions (nobody can access)
Security team discovers breach - customer database compromised, backdoor found
Emergency response: Server taken offline, forensics team called in
Damage assessment: 50,000 customer records stolen, server must be rebuilt from scratch
üìö Total cost: $150,000 in incident response, legal fees, and reputation damage
Developer learns: chmod 644 for files, 755 for directories. Never 777.

outcome: One careless chmod 777 command led to a complete security breach, data theft, and massive financial loss. The 5 seconds it took to type that command cost the company $150,000 and weeks of recovery time.
lessons_learned: chmod 777 is never the right solution - it's a security disaster waiting to happen
Use proper permissions: 644 for files (rw-r--r--), 755 for directories (rwxr-xr-x)
Understand what each permission number means: 4=read, 2=write, 1=execute
The -R flag is dangerous - it applies permissions recursively to all files
If you have permission errors, fix the ownership (chown) or use specific permissions
Security scanners constantly search for misconfigured servers - they will find you
